Does frost still imprison the ground,</br>And Nature lie buried in snow?</br>From the Southward warm breezes are found</br>In muttering hoarse accents to blow.</br>Then torrents of water distill,</br>At once all the ice sweeps away,</br>To a river enlarges each rill,</br>And the vallies are fill'd with dismay.

Shall Nature in agony sigh,</br>And Pleasure, astound at the waste,</br>Dejected with fear turn her eye</br>From scenes so horiferous haste?</br>Yet hold, gentle Goddess, and turn;</br>The rooks are beginning to pair;</br>That Spring shall emerge from her urn,</br>The buds of the currant declare.

To prospects less chearless O speed</br>The Muse in her pastoral flight;</br>Come, Flora, enamel the mead,</br>Replenish the earth with delight.</br>Deny not your mantle of green,</br>The lanschape is naked and cold;</br>Your promise to paint o'er the scene</br>The elder's expansions unfold.

The snowdrop I see in the dell,</br>Bold herald, with Winter in rear;</br>Her looks her soft embassy tell,</br>She comes the sad season to chear.</br>The Daphne-mezereon I see,</br>The wood-laurel too is in bloom;</br>Protruding the vernal-sown pea,</br>Is ready to burst from its tomb.

Fair minstrel, as early as sweet,</br>Dear woodlark!  how welcome thy note;</br>That Janus has made his retreat,</br>We learn from thy musical throat.</br>As herself now expanded the day,</br>Soft Pity appears in the vale;</br>The sportsmen her mandates obey,</br>No longer the woodlands assail.

Nor longer with spaniel and gun,</br>In vest which the bushes defies,</br>Accusing the slow-rising sun,</br>To cover young Doriland hies.</br>The pheasant beneath the rude thorn</br>Her plumage unfearful may spread,</br>Or venture to pilfer the corn</br>The husbandman carefully shed.

No perils the covey annoy;</br>Securely the partridge may pair,</br>And taste of connubial joy,</br>As Phoebus impregnates the air.</br>But mercy is partial, for lo,</br>In the moor, and the marsh, and the fen,</br>The snipe feels the death-level'd blow,</br>And the woodcock still bleeds in the glen.

Should clouds in succession distress,</br>The landschapes still deluge in showers,</br>The snow on the cottages press,</br>Consigning to dullness the hours,</br>Yet sorrow disturbs not the soul</br>Content for her residence forms,</br>Although to the farthermost pole</br>Extends the rude blast of the storms.

Content, O with visage serene</br>Thy image unfold to my view!</br>Attendant be Innocence seen!</br>How mean is the wealth of Peru!</br>The bosom of calmness is thine;</br>Emit but thy silver-soft ray,</br>We hear from thy whispers divine</br>More musick than issue from May.

Pastora, with mirth fill my reed—</br>Can sounds more harmonious flow?</br>Panegyrics more justly proceed,</br>Than those which to Delia I owe.</br>For now the bless'd morning appears,</br>My Muse with enchantment to wing,</br>Another we add to her years—</br>The birth-day of Delia I sing.

Though naked and brown are the lawns,</br>And Winter still harrows the day,</br>Aurora transcendently dawns,</br>'Tis Delia has heighten'd my lay.</br>For her, with each Grace in her train,</br>Shall Spring in gay beauty appear,</br>The Summer's varieties reign,</br>And Winter no longer appear.

Prophetic methinks that my song</br>Awakens the earth-chearing breeze,</br>The thrushes their sonnet prolong,</br>The turtles soft coo in the trees;</br>The chaffinch their symphony hails,</br>The hedge-sparrow musick creates—</br>'Tis Cupid, my fair-one, prevails—</br>Presides o'er the plume-painted states.

A chaplet I'll weave for the morn,</br>The myrtle shall fly from her beds,</br>Young Flora the offering adorn,</br>And flourish wherever she treads.</br>Let Delia approve of my lays,</br>Accept of the garland I twine;</br>The Muse into honour she'll raise,</br>Whose Bard is her own Valentine.</br>
